body: @srkukarni i think that is a good approach. Let me refactor the code
I discussed with @srkukarni and we are going to leave the KakfaSource as it is for now
@srkukarni thanks for the review. I have addressed your comments
@merlimat Looking much better! I think going with the struct-based options is a good strategy. I left more comments, further cleaning up some things for consistency, etc.

Hi, just so you know, I just tried this docker-compose file, and I got:
```Rons-MBP:tmp raarts$ docker-compose up
Pulling conf-eu (apachepulsar/pulsar-test-latest-version:latest)...
ERROR: The image for the service you're trying to recreate has been removed. If you continue, volume data could be lost. Consider backing up your data before continuing.

Continue with the new image? [yN]y
Pulling conf-eu (apachepulsar/pulsar-test-latest-version:latest)...
ERROR: pull access denied for apachepulsar/pulsar-test-latest-version, repository does not exist or may require 'docker login'
```

so it may need more tweaking before it can be used by a casual passer-by like me..

Also, and I don't know of this is the right place for it, I went to [Docker Hub](https://hub.docker.com/r/apachepulsar/pulsar/) for the image, so I could create it myself, but the Dockerfile used to create that image isn't there to be found, which is uncommon. I did find it in this repo though, and did manage to build it. Unfortunately our company requires images to be built from Alpine. Just some thoughts. Keep up the good work.

@raarts these compose files are for testing the current master code. We cannot push images for these to dockerhub, as they are not official releases (apache legal reasons). So for now, you have to generate the images yourself from the repo.
retest this please // containers took a too long to start for integration test
@merlimat @sijie @srkukarni please review and make sure that all API breaking changes are in the PR
This PR was meant to be targeted to @merlimat's local branch. Closing this PR here.
@bruth @lucperkins some more polishing and added `context.Context` arg to `Send()`, `Receive()` and `Next()` calls. Please take another look.

@merlimat Looks good. I noticed that the `Ack` calls don't take a context, but they (in theory) should. Since they interface with C, I realize that doesn't translate. But do those calls take a timeout or deadline by chance? i.e. wait N milliseconds for the ack. If so, then a timeout can be derived from the context.

>  I noticed that the Ack calls don't take a context, but they (in theory) should. Since they interface with C, I realize that doesn't translate. But do those calls take a timeout or deadline by chance? i.e. wait N milliseconds for the ack. If so, then a timeout can be derived from the context.

@bruth Short answer: the ack calls in Go lib are all non-blocking with no failure option.

So, in C++ lib we have both sync and async options for "ack" operations. It was the same in Java, though we found out that there's not much need for sync acknowledgement, so we just rely on best-effort acks. The rationale: 
 * If an ack fail, for an application it's difficult to know what to do (retry the ack? that can be done internally by the library, without application intervention)
 * If the ack fail, it typically is because the consumer is disconnected from broker. In any case, the messages are going to be redelivered by broker.
 * Client library can batch acknowledgements to broker to improve efficiency. This is already done in Java and will be extended to C++ as well.

For this reasons, we have made the ack operation to immediately return success. We haven't changed the method signatures in Java to maintain compatibility, but in Go since this is a new API there's no need for sync vs async ack or even returning an error.

@merlimat Interesting, thanks for the explanation.

> we just rely on best-effort acks

So in other words, the command is sent to the server *optimistically* and if it fails the observation of this failure is a redelivery. Presumably (and as you said) if there is a connection issue, then the client library will retry sending the command transparently. But once it is sent we are assuming the ack will be handled.

So yes in this case you are right that the `context.Context` won't actually influence the outcome. That said, I am still torn if whether it should be part of the signature anyway for consistency or if there is any chance in the future acks could be synchronous. I will leave this for you to decide.
Hmmm. I'm not sure if Go vendoring really works with "the Apache way" given the need for license headers. I'll do some digging and see how other projects manage this.

@bruth We have already seen it's not useful to have sync acks (given that anyway there's no ack on the ack). Since we're already moving that API semantic in other langs already, I really don't foresee to go back to that model :)

@merlimat Sounds good. I will do another pass tomorrow morning, but the code looks good to me. Maybe you can try to convince a few others in the channel to review as well.

I would like to try it out locally. What build options must be used to do the build? Include `pulsar-client-cpp/lib/c` in the `CGO_LDFLAGS`?
@lucperkins can't you just exclude vendor directory from license header checking?
An alternative is to do `go get -d ./...` to fetch all dependencies

@merlimat True, but in the Go community that's considered sub-standard practice because there are no versions, which means that someone could make a breaking change in one of the linked libraries. Since there's only one external dependency here it's probably not such a big risk. I'm happy to defer that decision to others.
Oh, true. Isn't there a way to just pin the version of the dependencies?
I think you can pin a revision or tag (but I can be wrong)
@lucperkins @sijie  I have removed the only dependency in the latest updates to #1764. We shouldn't need this for now.
@jerrypeng FYI I'm going to add a description for `--autoAck` in a different PR.
@sijie Would you please help review this?
we might consider porting this change back for 2.0.1?

@lucperkins There are some missing headers: 

```
2018-05-17\T\16:27:06.785 [WARNING] Missing header in: /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/pulsar_precommit_java8/site/_data/deps.yaml
2018-05-17\T\16:27:06.799 [WARNING] Missing header in: /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/pulsar_precommit_java8/site/_includes/python-deps.html
```
@merlimat Someday I'll remember on my own grrrrrr. Fixed.

I have a couple more comments:

- Rename `MessageBuilder` to a `ProducerMessage` since it is no longer implements a builder pattern?
- It may be useful to include the message in `SendAsync` error callback in order to correlate the error to the message.

A couple more observations:

- There should be control over logging, either turning it off or provide an interface to wrap it somehow so the structure can be controlled.
- I noticed I could not create a binary that statically linked libpulsar. This could be my environment, but this was the output:

```
/usr/local/Cellar/go/1.10.1/libexec/pkg/tool/darwin_amd64/link: running clang failed: exit status 1
ld: library not found for -lcrt0.o
```
This looks good for now, however in the future lets have tighter integration with the schema registry.  So the user doesn't need to write or compile any code to use a connector
@jaoki could you please address my comments?
Hi @turboT4, can you specify which pulsar version and which environment OS / Java version?
Thanks for the reply @merlimat , I'm trying to run Pulsar on macOS Sierra and Java version 1.8.0_121.
@lucperkins do you mind rebasing this PR?
@srkukarni @sijie I'd love to close this out but it has been a bit busy. Would it be OK if I come back in a couple of weeks?
test failing, looks legit. Will look into it.

>  Rename MessageBuilder to a ProducerMessage since it is no longer implements a builder pattern?

Yes, I didn't want to call it `Message` or `MessageOptions`, `ProducerMessage` sounds good.

>  It may be useful to include the message in SendAsync error callback in order to correlate the error to the message.

Yes, mostly in C++ or Java you attach that by adding the value on the lambda. Changed it here

>  There should be control over logging, either turning it off or provide an interface to wrap it somehow so the structure can be controlled.

Good point, the log4cxx based logger was a bit overkill and not well integrated. Replaced now and allow to set logger function callback.

> I noticed I could not create a binary that statically linked libpulsar. This could be my environment, but this was the output:

This I think is more related to cgo and MacOS. I have the same but it was working on linux.

Great changes.

> This I think is more related to cgo and MacOS. I have the same but it was working on linux.

Good to know. I will be deploying on Linux so that works for me.
